title: Clashes expected in Hong Kong as protesters try to spoil China’s 70th anniversary celebrations
text:
A protester holds a sign that reads, “No National Day, only martyrdom,” as anti-government protesters march in Wang Chai district in Hong Kong on Tuesday, while the celebration of the 70th anniversary of the People’s Republic is taking place in Beijing. (Vincent Thian/AP)

The fire-red Chinese flag was hoisted soon after day broke in Hong Kong on Tuesday, accompanied by the rousing national anthem, billowing in a square overlooking the glimmering Victoria Harbor: a ceremonial nod to the territory’s sovereign masters on their 70th anniversary.

But no officials were to be seen. They were all inside a sprawling convention center hall, watching the ceremony on an LED screen. A designated public viewing area was empty, without anyone around to clap and cheer. Roads surrounding the ceremony were shut, as were nearby subway stations. The pomp and circumstance was reduced to a lone tugboat chugging through Victoria Harbor, water cannons spraying in the air and two helicopters towing flags flying past. An annual fireworks show planned for the evening was scrapped.

The muted celebrations underscore heightened tensions here as protesters and police gear up for what is billed to be perhaps the most significant — and violent — day in almost four months of sustained demonstrations in the Chinese semiautonomous territory.

Protesters are hoping to send a clear message to Beijing on the 70th anniversary of Chinese Communist Party rule: Protect Hong Kong’s freedoms and grant it full democracy, or face continued and unending dissent designed to shame Chinese President Xi Jinping at a sensitive time in his tenure. Authorities are responding by putting in the city in lockdown mode, closing almost two dozen shopping malls, roads and key subway stations while warning of chaos.

“We have to send a message to the government and the police, that we are not afraid of them, and that going out to protest is our right,” said Fok, a 24-year-old who spoke on the condition that he be identified only by his last name, as he was already arrested once over protest participation. “It is time to show China they picked the wrong people to bully. This is a war, and we will win it.”

Police warned of violence ahead of the anniversary, after another bloody and chaotic weekend of unauthorized protest in the city. At a news conference Monday, Tse Chun-chung, chief superintendent of the police’s public relations branch, warned that the city was “on the verge of extreme danger.”

“All acts are one step closer to terrorism,” he said. “We are deeply concerned about public safety tomorrow and we express the strongest condemnation against all criminal and violent acts.”

The police force also sent text messages to all in Hong Kong, warning residents to stay alert and brace for “severe disruptions.”

The protests started as a rebuke against a now-scrapped piece of legislation that would have allowed fugitives to be transferred from Hong Kong’s independent legal system to mainland China. But perceptions of government inaction and shock over police use of force has turned the movement into a full-blown rebuke of Beijing’s tightening controls over the city, and revived a years-long demand for direct elections of city leaders.

Protesters have settled on a list of five demands — withdrawal of the extradition bill was just one of them — but the government has declined to make further concessions, including an independent investigation into the police.

Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam traveled to Beijing with a delegation of more than 240 people to attend the anniversary extravaganza there, which will include a show of Chinese military firepower. Lam’s party was made up of business tycoons and pro-Beijing lawmakers.

Matthew Cheung, the territory’s chief secretary, took over as acting chief executive in her absence and delivered Hong Kong’s national day speech.

Hong Kong’s special status under “One Country, Two Systems,” Cheung said, has rendered “it the most open and freest city” in China.

Recent instability, however, “has seriously undermined social order and impacted the rule of law.”

“Shocked and saddened by the violence that has turned the city that we call home into an unfamiliar place, Hong Kong people desperately yearn to get out of the existing gridlock,” Cheung said, adding that his government has shown the “greatest sincerity” in offering a dialogue with the community.

Timothy McLaughlin and Tiffany Liang contributed to this report.
